metadata.notes: SolarWinds SUNBURST supply chain compromise (December 2020). Attack path: #10 ||[update][@Vendor→@Org]|| →[Δt=instant] #7 →[Δt=~14d] #4 →[Δt=~2h] #1 + [DRE: C]. APT29/Cozy Bear attributed (Axiom IV: actor identity does not change cluster classification). Sources: CISA Alert AA20-352A, Microsoft MSRC, FireEye/Mandiant UNC2452 report.

path_sequence.notes: Trust Acceptance Event: SolarWinds Orion update v2019.4-2020.2.1 containing SUNBURST backdoor accepted and installed by target organization via legitimate update channel. The compromised DLL (SolarWinds.Orion.Core.BusinessLayer.dll) was digitally signed by SolarWinds, passing all trust verification. Falsifiability test: removing the third-party trust link (not accepting the update) would have prevented this step.

FEC execution via designed capability: SUNBURST backdoor DLL loaded and executed by the legitimate SolarWinds Orion service (solarwinds.businesslayerhost.exe). The execution used the environment's intended DLL loading mechanism — an intended data→code transition, not an exploit. SUNBURST remained dormant for approximately 12-14 days before activating C2 communication via DNS (avsvmcloud.com). R-EXEC satisfied: FEC execution recorded as #7.

Credential application: attacker forged SAML tokens using stolen signing certificates to impersonate legitimate users and access cloud resources (Azure AD, Office 365). Per Axiom X: the acquisition of the signing key occurred during the #7 step (a consequence of the malware's access, recorded as DRE:C); the USE of forged credentials to authenticate is always #4 regardless of acquisition method.

Abuse of legitimate cloud functions: attacker used valid (forged) credentials to abuse Azure AD APIs, Office 365 mail reading APIs, and federated trust configurations for data exfiltration. No code flaw exploited — the attacker operated within the designed functionality of the cloud platform using stolen identity. Data stayed data; no foreign code was introduced at this stage.
